awd_titl_txt: Probe the conformational dynamics of a protein targeting machine at single molecule resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Observing the dynamic movements of molecular machines in action and deciphering their roles in biological function are the frontiers of life science research. This project aims to elucidate the molecular movements in a protein targeting machine, the signal recognition particle (SRP), as it delivers ~30% of newly synthesized proteins to the correct biological membrane in the cell. The project will generate valuable reagents, tools, and assays that are useful to many other researchers. The results of the research will be disseminated through publications in academic journals as well as animated movie illustrations that will be available to the general public. The education component of the proposal will emphasize the training of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in multidisciplinary biochemical and biophysical research. It will also expose high school and undergraduate students to state-of-the-art research tools and provide leadership experience for the graduate students and postdocs.

More specifically, this project will combine the expertise of the Shan lab in mechanistic biochemistry and the Weiss lab in biophysics to decipher the dynamic motions that drive co-translational protein targeting by SRP at single molecule resolution. The recent works by the Shan lab indicated the presence of multiple largescale conformational rearrangements in SRP during the protein targeting cycle. This project will develop solution-based single molecule fluorescence assays to directly observe the conformational rearrangements in SRP during targeting, decipher the molecular forces that drive them, and understand their regulation by the GTPase cycle of SRP and by spatial and temporal signals in the pathway. The results will elucidate the molecular basis for the spatiotemporal control of this targeting machine, and reveal generalizable principles that underlie the action of nucleotide-driven macromolecular machines in biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome (final report)

 

Proper protein localization is essential for the maintenance of protein homeostasis and compartmentalization in all cells.Signal recognition particle (SRP) is a universally conserved pathway responsible for the cotranslational delivery of >30% of the newly synthesized proteome, and has served as a paradigm for understanding the molecular basis of protein localization. As a targeting machine, SRP has evolved to perform a highly sophisticated sequence of largescale molecular rearrangements. Importantly, these movements provide potential points for regulation by the substrate, nucleotide, and the membrane translocase, thus effecting the spatiotemporal accuracy and potentially enhancing the fidelity of the pathway. Using single molecule spectroscopy approaches together with biochemical reconstitutions, molecular genetics and cryo-electron microscopy, we have deciphered the complex series of molecular rearrangements in the mammalian SRP-SRP receptor complex that drive targeting and elucidated their regulation by spatial and temporal signals. In addition, we elucidated how an essential cotranslational chaperone regulates the conformation of SRP to help select the correct proteins for targeting to the ER. Our work provided unprecedented resolution in our understanding of this fundamental cellular pathway, and revealed general principles that enable the balance between efficiency and fidelity during protein biogenesis and localization.

 

This research also served as a general paradigm to conceptualize the mechanism and regulation of many other molecular machineries. The interdisciplinary approach described here enables surgical precision in our ability to interrogate the SRP pathway, and provides conceptual and experimental blueprints to inform similar studies in other complex biological pathways. 

Our research and education programs also provided ample opportunities for exchanges across disciplines and for exposure of both young (high school and undergraduate students) and mature scientists (graduate students and postdocs) to state-of-the-art single molecule biophysics and modern integrated biochemistry, and will enable the next generation of life scientists to be well versed in interdisciplinary research. Members of both the PI and co-PI’s groups come from all over the world, represent both genders, and are racially and ethnically diverse. Unifying these scientists is the commitment that understanding the activity, interaction, dynamics and structures of macromolecules provide the most fundamental answers to important biological questions. The research carried out in this project directly impact the training of these scientists. It also presented opportunities to impact the general public by the generation and public sharing 3D videos (produced based on the results of this study) of cotranslational protein targeting and on single molecule fluorescence spectroscopy methods to investigate these problems.
